title: How to Have Multiple Wireless Door Chimes Work Together

steps.headline: Lay the units out on a flat surface and pull all the batteries out of all the Receivers and Transmitters you have.
Put the battery back into one of the Transmitters.
Select a unique code setting on this Transmitter by following the manufacturer's instruction manual.
Put batteries into one of the Receivers.
steps.description: Depending on the unit you have, it may signal connection to the Transmitter (usually by beeping).

steps.headline: Test reception by pressing the button on the Transmitter.
steps.description: Chime should sound on (and only on) the Receiver in the Step above.

steps.headline: Remove the battery from the Transmitter.
steps.description: Leave the batteries in the Receiver. Wait 30 seconds before proceeding.

steps.headline: Repeat Steps 2 to 6 inclusive for each Transmitter/Receiver pair.
steps.description: If more than one of the Receivers chimes when you push the Transmitter button in Step 5, go back and select a different code in Step 3, remove the batteries from the Receiver, wait 30 seconds and then repeat Steps 4 and 5.

steps.headline: Wrap all the Receivers together in aluminum foil.
steps.description: Get about 3-4 layers of foil around all of the Receivers (you don't need to wrap them individually). The foil acts as a EMI/EMC shield from the Transmitters.

steps.headline: Remove the bundled Receivers to a location at least 5 metres (15 feet) from the Transmitters.
Put the batteries back into all of the Transmitters.
You can bring back and unwrap the Receivers now and test them together with their Transmitters.
steps.description: Only the respective Receiver should chime for each button press of a Transmitter.

steps.headline: If your Transmitter supports it, now select the individual tune you want for the chime following the manufacturer's instructions, so that they don't all sound the same!

text: Lay the units out on a flat surface and pull all the batteries out of all the Receivers and Transmitters you have. Wait thirty seconds before proceeding. Put the battery back into one of the Transmitters.  Select a unique code setting on this Transmitter by following the manufacturer's instruction manual.  Put batteries into one of the Receivers. Depending on the unit you have, it may signal connection to the Transmitter (usually by beeping). Test reception by pressing the button on the Transmitter. Chime should sound on (and only on) the Receiver in the Step above. Remove the battery from the Transmitter. Leave the batteries in the Receiver. Wait 30 seconds before proceeding. Repeat Steps 2 to 6 inclusive for each Transmitter/Receiver pair. If more than one of the Receivers chimes when you push the Transmitter button in Step 5, go back and select a different code in Step 3, remove the batteries from the Receiver, wait 30 seconds and then repeat Steps 4 and 5. Wrap all the Receivers together in aluminum foil. Get about 3-4 layers of foil around all of the Receivers (you don't need to wrap them individually). The foil acts as a EMI/EMC shield from the Transmitters. Remove the bundled Receivers to a location at least 5 metres (15 feet) from the Transmitters.  Put the batteries back into all of the Transmitters.  You can bring back and unwrap the Receivers now and test them together with their Transmitters. Only the respective Receiver should chime for each button press of a Transmitter. If your Transmitter supports it, now select the individual tune you want for the chime following the manufacturer's instructions, so that they don't all sound the same!
